awd_titl_txt: Two-dimensional protein arrays: de novo design and applications
awd_abstract_narration:
1401835 
Baneyx, Francois C. 

Two dimensional (2D) protein arrays are of considerable interest for the production of advanced materials, devices and systems. For instance, the naturally occurring purple membrane patches of archaeal cells have been exploited for optical information storage; 2D protein layers isolated from archaea and bacteria have been used to produce next generation vaccines and as templates for the fabrication of nanostructured inorganic materials. Yet, these technologies have not evolved beyond proof of concept because they are not robust or scalable, and because neither the geometry, nor the chemistry or assembly of these systems can be precisely controlled from the nano- to the mesoscale. In this work, it is proposed to create an entirely new generation of self-assembled 2D scaffolds that have been designed from the ground up to enable the next generation of advanced materials, biosensors and biodevices. The project seamlessly blends computation, molecular biology, biochemistry, biotechnology, and materials science, and provides a unique opportunity to train students in truly interdisciplinary research. One underrepresented undergraduate student will be paired with a graduate student to broaden participation in science. Results and lessons from the proposed work will be presented to the public and a week-long module on self-assembly will be developed for inclusion in the department's Molecular Engineering curriculum.  

It is proposed to computationally design a family of proteins that will be capable of robust self-assembly into 2D arrays by fusing protomers from symmetry-compatible oligomers and redesigning interfacial contacts between unit cells. We will delineate and optimize self-assembly conditions for scalable formation of 2D arrays retaining short-range order at the nanoscale but growing over hundreds of micrometers. We will develop approaches to stack these lattices into periodic 3D structures, and apply strategies to control the adsorption and orientation of 2D arrays at technological-relevant interfaces through electrostatic interactions, surface modification and the engineering of solid binding peptides within permissive sites of the structure. And finally, we will explore the potential of these designer 2D lattices as tunable molds for templating inorganic mineralization and as scaffolds for high-density display of enzymes and proteins and for membrane protein crystallization.

por.por_cntn:
On the intellectual merit front, this project has provided the first demonstration that an oligomeric protein with c6 symmetry can be computationally redesigned to self-assemble into two-dimensional (2D) arrays capable of growing to dozens of micrometers while retaining order at the nanoscale. Although topological characteristics (flat faces pierced by pores with a diameter inferior to 3 nm) were specified as design parameters, self-assembly was found to be dependent on a chemical trigger – the addition of divalent cations to the solution. Far from being a bug, this feature proved highly valuable to control the initiation and kinetics of 2D array assembly.

This project has further led to the demonstration that the 2D protein lattices so created are versatile platforms for the construction of hybrid architectures that hold promise for applications in health, sensing and energy. Indeed, genetic modification of the protruding ends of constituent protomers can be performed to: drive the attachment of self-assembled arrays to polymeric beads; capture and assemble noble metal nanoparticles into planar geometries; and control the immobilization density of proteins at array surfaces by mixing wild type and biotinylated protomers at defined ratios. 

Additionally, we have demonstrated that fusion of a silica-binding extension to passenger proteins mediates their entrapment within high surface area sol-gels, and that arginine supplementation can be used to induce their dynamic release from the inorganic matrix. 

On the broader impact front, this project this project has showcased how "green" and bottom-­up bio­inspired approaches can be used for the fabrication of complex nanomaterials and hierarchical structures without resorting to complicated, energy-­intensive processes or generating hazardous wastes; it has served to further establish the power of computational protein design in nanofabrication, and it has introduced examples of bionanotechnologies that are easy to understand and teach. Graduate students supported by the award have received a unique interdisciplinary training at the intersection of computational protein design, molecular biology, protein biochemistry, biotechnology, materials chemistry, and nanotechnology. They have designed and staffed a demonstration booth titled “Chemical Wizardry” for three consecutive years at the University of Washington Engineering Discovery Days, a campus-wide event that draws thousands of elementary, middle, and high school students; mentored 5th grade students for science fair projects and high school students through the TAF academy; organized a summer-long program hosting outstanding graduate and post-doctoral students interested in academic careers; and they have gained leadership skill as President of the UW chapter of SACNAS. Graduate students have also mentored two under-represented undergraduate students who participated in the research. Finally, the project has supported the development of an educational module in protein self-assembly.
